messageBody:
Hi There,

We use JUnit pretty extensively for our distributed application
both as a unit test tool and as a driver for integration testing.
We created a TestSuite which allows us to run multiple servers
and clients in the same VM talking to each other via sockets.
Running in the same VM is much easier to implement and gives you
easy control of any timing issues. The only thing you have
to watch out for is any static code (i.e. the popular singleton
accessor). Email me if you need additional help.

On a related note I saw a reply mentioning Joshua. Since the
code wasn't available we threw together a distributed test
runner using NFS and SSH. Allows us to parallelize our
unit test runs across about a dozen boxes. Since we do
several integration tests using the junit framework it
helps testing time tremendously.

Cheers!

Mike


> -----Original Message-----
> From: guillaume_berche [mailto:guillaume.berche@...]
> Sent: Monday, January 21, 2002 8:49 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Junit support for non-standard distributed
> applications
>
>
> Hello,
>
> I'm working on a Java layer implementing various communication
> infrastructrure betwen processes based on raw TCP and UDP. I would
> like to test it using Junit. However, this requires me to write a
> test case which is distributed among many processes which act as
> client/servers.
>
> I've looked into jakarta's cactus, and Junit EE but I understand they
> would support only distributed applications based on standard
> communication protocols (namely HTTP and an EJB contained)
>
> Is there an extension to Junit that would support testing of non-
> standard distributed applications?
>
> I've started designing an RMI-based version of the junit interfaces
> where a testcase could spawn one or more "distributed test cases"
> running on remote hosts and that would report their status through
> the originating test's TestListener. I'm basically remotizing the
> junit interfaces.
>
> I wonder if such extension would already exist and if I could reuse
> it rather than redoing this from scratch.
>
> Thanks for your help,
>
> Guillaume.
